title: 105_hr2807
content:
The "Migratory Bird Treaty Reform Act of 1998" prohibits the taking of migratory game birds by baiting and imposes criminal penalties for violations. SEC. 103 of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act is amended to increase fines for violations and introduce imprisonment for offenders. SEC. 104 requires a report on the impact of the amendments on bird conservation and law enforcement efforts. The "National Wildlife Refuge System Improvement Act of 1998" includes provisions for the Upper Mississippi River National Wildlife and Fish Refuge. The Upper Mississippi River Wildlife and Fish Refuge in Minnesota is transferring approximately 37.36 acres of land to the Corps of Engineers without reimbursement. The Upper Mississippi River Wild Life and Fish Refuge Act is being amended to change the name to Upper Mississippi River National Wildlife and Fish Refuge. SEC. 203. Termination of jurisdiction over Killcohook Coordination Area in NJ and DE, established by Executive Orders 6582 and 8648. Executive Orders revoked. SEC. 204. Establishment of Lake Elsie National Wildlife Refuge. SEC. 204. Lake Elsie National Wildlife Refuge jurisdiction terminated, Executive Order 8152 revoked. SEC. 205. Klamath Forest National Wildlife Refuge renamed Klamath Marsh National Wildlife Refuge. SEC. 206. Violation of National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act. SEC. 206. VIOLATION OF NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE SYSTEM ADMINISTRATION ACT. Amendment to penalties for violations of the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966, including fines and imprisonment for knowing violations and other non-compliance. TITLE III--WETLANDS AND WILDLIFE ENHANCEMENT

SEC. 301. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as the "Wetlands and Wildlife Enhancement Act of 1998".

SEC. 302. REAUTHORIZATION OF NORTH AMERICAN WETLANDS CONSERVATION ACT.

Amends the North American Wetlands Conservation Act to allocate $30,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2003.

SEC. 303. REAUTHORIZATION OF PARTNERSHIPS FOR WILDLIFE ACT.

Amends the Partnerships for Wildlife Act to allocate $6,250,000 for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2003.

SEC. 304. MEMBERSHIP OF THE NORTH AMERICAN WETLANDS CONSERVATION COUNCIL. During 1999-2002, the North American Wetlands Conservation Council membership includes a Ducks Unlimited, Inc. Group Manager and 2 individuals appointed by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary must publish a policy for appointments by June 30, 1999. Appointments under section 4(a)(1)(D) of the North American Wetlands Conservation Act. The title of this section is the "Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1998". It includes findings related to the conservation of these animals. Congress finds that the populations of all but 1 species of rhinoceros and the tiger have significantly declined and continue to decline. These species are listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 and on Appendix I of CITES. Resolutions have been adopted urging Parties to CITES to implement legislation to reduce illegal trade in their parts and products. The decline in tiger and rhinoceros populations is primarily due to poaching for traditional medicines. Legal mechanisms are lacking to stop the trade of products containing substances from these species. Legislation is needed to control the trade of these parts and derivatives. The importation and exportation of products containing rhinoceros or tiger parts into or from the United States is prohibited. Efforts are being made to educate people about the illegality of these products and the need to conserve these species. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 prohibits the sale, importation, and exportation of products containing substances derived from rhinoceros or tiger species intended for human consumption or application. SEC. 404 of the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 defines 'person' as an individual, corporation, partnership, trust, association, government entity, or any other entity subject to the jurisdiction of the United States. SEC. 405 prohibits the sale, importation, or exportation of products labeled or advertised as rhinoceros or tiger products under the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994. Prohibition on selling, importing, or exporting products containing substances from rhinoceros or tiger species. Criminal penalties include fines and imprisonment for violators. Civil penalties may also be imposed by the Secretary. The Secretary may assess civil penalties in a manner similar to the Endangered Species Act. Products violating the prohibition may be seized and forfeited. Regulations will be issued to enforce this section. The Secretaries will enforce this section similarly to the Endangered Species Act. Penalty amounts collected will be used as per the Lacey Act Amendments. SEC. 406. EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH PROGRAM. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 is amended to include a new section on an educational outreach program. The Secretary will develop an educational outreach program in the US for rhinoceros and tiger conservation, including guidelines and information on laws protecting the species, traditional medicines, and the status of the species. SEC. 407 of the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 is amended to authorize appropriations for 1996 through 2002. TITLE V introduces the Chesapeake Bay Initiative Act of 1998, including provisions for Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the EPA Administrator, will provide assistance to identify, conserve, and interpret resources in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. This includes linking sites with trails for public education and access. The Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails Network aims to connect sites with trails, water routes, and other connections within the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. Components may include parks, seaports, historical sites, and public access sites selected by the Secretary. The program also includes a grants assistance program. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Administrator, will establish a Chesapeake Bay Gateways Grants Assistance Program to aid in conserving, restoring, and interpreting resources within the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. Criteria for grants will be developed, and grants will cover up to 50% of project costs with the condition of non-Federal matching funds. Authorization of Appropriations.--$3,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2003 to cover eligible project costs, with a requirement that no more than 10% be used for administrative expenses. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
